body.p: Our goal is to streamline the server installation process such that you can have RabbitMQ up and running within two minutes of completing your download. If this doesn't happen to you, please let us know at legitimategrievance@rabbitmq.com!
The RabbitMQ server is an implementation of an AMQP broker. Please see the specification page for more information on AMQP interoperation and standards-conformance.

RabbitMQ is written on top of the widely-used Open Telecom Platform, and is platform neutral; the binary distributions listed below differ only in how they are packaged to conform to various operating systems' packaging conventions.

In order to compile or run the server, you will need to have downloaded and installed Erlang/OTP, version R12B-3 or higher. Your operating system may come with a package for working with Erlang, or you may need to download and install Erlang yourself.
Please see the Installation instructions. Additional documentation can be found linked from our documentation page.
The server is open-source, and is licensed under the Mozilla Public License v1.1.
The current release of the RabbitMQ Server is &version-server;.
The server is available as source, or compiled in a few different forms. Notes on particular operating systems and variants can be found below the download table.

The openSUSE RPM files are intended for Novell's openSUSE Linux and derived distributions (SLES and SLERT). We haven't tested these under recent releases, but expect that they work.
If you have success using our RPMs with any other RPM-based distribution, please let us know.

We strongly recommend using your distribution's packaged version of Erlang to run the server. This is part of Fedora, and in EPEL for RHEL. To enable EPEL on your Red Hat machine, see the EPEL FAQ. Then just yum install erlang.
On OS X the server can be installed via MacPorts.
Alternatively, for users of the homebrew package manager there is a community-contributed 'rabbitmq' formula.
The architecture-neutral binary package from the table above can be used on any Unix or Linux variant.
Amazon EC2 Images containing Ubuntu 9.10 (Karmic Koala), both 32 and 64 bit variants, are available for download with pre-installed RabbitMQ.
The RabbitMQ server itself, implemented in Erlang. Depends on the code-generation library module. Please see the build instructions.
For help compiling or installing RabbitMQ, or for general queries, please contact us.
